Ah, there's nothing quite like bringing out your favorite car that's been sitting dormant all winter and going for a nice evening cruise. emoticon_xgood
I voted No, cars are for transportation only, only because it was the only "no" option. Money's for rich people.
I have garage queens and always welcome clear weather. Our winter weather isn't always inclement and almost any clear day (with dry streets) brings out the classics and rods.

Classic, Muscle, and G machine.

 
 There ya go. emoticon_xgood emoticon_xgood

I have garage queens and always welcome clear weather. Our winter weather isn't always inclement and almost any clear day (with dry streets) brings out the classics and rods.

 
 I wish I had a garage queen. Unfortunately, my Camaro sits out in the snow while my son's gets the use of the garage for his twin turbo Camaro that we just finished building. emoticon_cry

I voted No, cars are for transportation only, only because it was the only "no" option. Money's for rich people.

 
 What's the matter? Can't anybody in KC afford to have 2 cars? emoticon_wow

Yes I am a car/truck nut, but no to the first five options. I currently have only have my wife's '04 Taurus and my '04 Ranger. I have owned many customs and hot rods over the years, but I recently sold my '60 Triumph TR3 roadster and vowed (again) not to start any more long term projects. I just finished putting leather seats in the Ranger and I've almost finished the custom console I am building.
 Dono

What's the matter? Can't anybody in KC afford to have 2 cars? emoticon_wow

 Why have more than 1 car? You can only drive one at a time anyway.
 
 By the way, I voted no because while I think cars are cool, I would rather have my 98 Chevy Malibu than a Mustang from the 60's or whatever. I'd also rather have the Malibu than any muscle car or sports car. Probably the only thing I would want more than having the Malibu that I have now would be a smaller car. I don't really care for big cars. Not that the Malibu is big, I've just seen smaller; not to mention smaller cars have better gas mileage.

 Vehicle perception is often dependent on income level.

Vehicle perception is often dependent on income level.

 What do you mean by this specifically?

Vehicle perception is often dependent on income level.

 That's interesting. I thought it would be that the ability to buy a new car would be dependent on income level. But how can the amount of money you make change how you see a car. The only difference is the kind you're able to purchase and pay taxes on (and gas prices.) But a car is a car.

What do you mean by this specifically?

 
 While any vehicle can and will provide transportation, there's literally a world of difference between driving say a basic VW and a high-end Mercedes. That includes personal safety, comfort and drivability. The ability to choose between basic and superior transportation is most often determined by financial means, not unlike flying coach or first class. In both instances, once experienced and affordable, going back to basics can best be described as uncomfortable.

But a car is a car.

 
 They all do the same job, but from my personal viewpoint some cars are far, far superior to others by any measure.
I have ridden in some expensive cars, or at least sports cars, and I'm still more comfortable sitting in a Malibu.

I have ridden in some expensive cars, or at least sports cars, and I'm still more comfortable sitting in a Malibu.

 
 To each his own. A leather covered, heated, lumbar/height/backrest angle/steering wheel proximity controlled electric seat also makes for some comfortable sitting. Especially when surrounded by engineered production directed at superior performance.

Personally, I like big old Ford trucks. 
 
 But I'm a poor student and have no need for a vehicle, so I just take the bus.

Personally, I like big old Ford trucks. 
 
 But I'm a poor student and have no need for a vehicle, so I just take the bus.

 
 My kinda gal, I have three big old Ford trucks, the one that I make a living with is extra big! :)

I used to want a really special Italian car - perhaps something like a Maserati or maybe a big Lancia. Never got anything like that of course.
 
 But I once owned an Alfasud - a sort of poor man's Alfa Romeo - and running it was like setting fire to banknotes. It drank fuel, leaked oil, let in the rain, and rusted perceptibly when I looked at it. I had to more or less give it away in part exchange.
 
 For years now I've stuck with Japanese cars, Nissan, Mazda, and now Toyota. Not exciting vehicles, but reliable and the depreciation is very reasonable.

I recall the first new car I ever owned, a 1960 Triumph TR3 roadster. As we perpared for vacation, my wife (also new) told me I had a choice, "We can take clothes or your golf clubs". When I didn't answer, she said, "Well"? "I'm thinking, I'm thinking", I replied.
 Dono

Why have more than 1 car? You can only drive one at a time anyway.

 Do you only have one golf club? Different vehicles for different functions.

I'd also rather have the Malibu than any muscle car or sports car. Probably the only thing I would want more than having the Malibu that I have now would be a smaller car. I don't really care for big cars. Not that the Malibu is big, I've just seen smaller; not to mention smaller cars have better gas mileage.

 The revised Malibus are the most anemic Chevelles ever produced. For the life of me, I can't figure out why anyone would want a 4-door, front-wheel drive Chevelle with a lawn mower engine.... especially after having driven a 1970 SS396 in the past. emoticon_confused

I recall the first new car I ever owned, a 1960 Triumph TR3 roadster. As we perpared for vacation, my wife (also new) told me I had a choice, "We can take clothes or your golf clubs". When I didn't answer, she said, "Well"? "I'm thinking, I'm thinking", I replied.
 Dono

 
 You were fortunate. My first new car was a 1965 Chevrolet, 4-dr, 283, full power including AC and a real dog. A company car. I ran it head-on into a light pole at about 30mph the night before leaving for an extended training period in Atlanta. Neither of us was injured, the attending police weren't giving field sobriety tests in those days, overlooked the fact I had been celebrating and I flew out the next morning. Ah, the good old corporate days.

 My first car was a 1967 Impala SS with a 283, 2 barrel carb and slip and slide powerglide. It was a real land yacht. I put cheater slicks and air shocks on the back and raised the bumber to chest level. LOL Youth, it's wasted on the young. emoticon_wow 
 My first "new car" was a 1983 Pontiac J2000 Station Wagon with a whopping 4-cylinder 1.8l engine. What a POS! I replaced two warped aluminum heads before finally dumping it in 1989. :xcensored

"First cars" could be a whole new thread, but it's well enough under way here - may I continue? :) 
 
 My first was a 48 F-1 Ford pickup. Six years older than me!! It had been sitting for years in a field of a farm where I worked as a lad of 13. (about 2 miles from home - rode my bicycle back and fourth) The engine was locked up, but it wasn't the original flathead engine. It had been converted to a mid fifties Oldsmobile engine. Re-welded mounts, and an adaptor plate to couple it to the original truck transmission. It had Oldsmobile~ROCKET~on the valve covers. Impressive eh? I wasn't impressed - I was as much a Ford guy then as I am now. But the farmer assured me that the best way to get it running would be to find another Olds engine like it. He required $40 worth of farm work for it, and it was mine! After earning another $40 (the going price for used engines at that time) he took me to a junkyard to get an engine for it, and we sat it in on the farm with the tractor & boom. Then early one Sunday morning (when traffic was lightest) I pulled it to my house all by my 13 year old self with his tractor & V tow bar. Quite a feeling to watch that thing follow me home!
 
 Needless to say, in the 2+ years I had before I could get my drivers licence, I had plenty of time to get it ready, and ready it was when I was 16! An orange brush-paint job (with 2 6" spray can racing stripes) some nice wide Chrysler Imperial rims & 14" tires, and dual exhausts peeking out from under the rear bumper! It looked just fine in the high school parking lot! Pickups weren't very common in 1971, especially among teenagers. 
 
 Always had trouble with that truck, mainly the engine - it didn't last. Replaced it in a little over a year with a 50 F-2. (Cannibalized the 48) It had the original flathead V-8, it was a good old truck. I still had it a few years later when I bought the only new vehicle I ever bought - a 74 F-100. Got a picture of them side by side when the 74 was only about a week old. Ended up driving the 74 for 20 years! By the time I was 38 years old, it dawned on me that I had that truck for half my life! Pretty well worn out by then, but the cab & doghouse didn't have much rust. Later used them on a 1 ton frame. Not running today, but I still have it. 
 
 Funny thing is, when I was fixing up that 48 it seemed like it was ancient - it was about 20 years old at the time. I have a 71 F-250 in my garage right now (almost done) and it doesn't seem that old to me, and it's 35 years old!!!! I guess it's MY age that's changed my perspective!! :)

Thanks for sharing your story, Marc. Soungs like you got a deal on the truck. emoticon_xgood 
 I paid $150 for my 67 Impala SS and another $35 for a junkyard fender to repalce the one that was dented when I bought the car. Its paintjob can only be described as "primitive". The long sloping decklid, for example, appeared to have been painted with a roller and crinkle finish housepaint, but it ran and that's all that mattered at the time. :)
